channel.title: Comments on: What Is A Database Abstraction Layer?

item.title: By: Artemi Krymski
item.dc:creator: Artemi Krymski
item.description: Totally agree with you. I've developed a simple database abstraction layer (SDBA) that cleanly separates DB-specific access functions and provides a *very* simple interface, aimed at productivity. Different implementations of SDBA for different databases are being worked on. The query function "understands" SQL queries and returns different things if its a SELECT, UPDATE, or INSERT. Let me know what you think. Here it is: http://www.morewhite.com/sdba

item.title: By: yarcles
item.dc:creator: yarcles
item.description:
Hell, why dont you just call it a Database Access ABSTRACTION layer, since its â€˜disassociated from any specific database access implementation(instance)â€™.
"Database abstraction layer" shouldnt have such a rigid definition to be only for abstracting a RDBMS in totality.
I would suggest its general usage is any abstraction relating to database implementation like access, SQL portability, logging etc. but does not have to include them all.
And if you want to then get specific which parts of db abstraction you are talking aboutyou can.
I know its all just terminology but it seems a lot of ppl in these threads are selectively using the term abstraction to prove a point.

item.title: By: Betcour
item.dc:creator: Betcour
item.description: Excellent analysis. I use a database access layer myself - mostly because I needed some way to simulate nested transactions within MySQL (which only support non-nested transactions).
